question: Should state school teachers be paid based on merit?

content.source_1: Chetty, Friedman, and Rockoff (2014, American Economic Review) — Using tax and school records, the authors show that students assigned to high–value-added teachers have higher college attendance, adult earnings, and lower teen birth rates. Implication: If “merit” is credibly measured (e.g., via robust value-added), rewarding more effective teachers could yield long-run student benefits.
content.source_2: American Statistical Association (ASA) Statement on Using Value-Added Models for Educational Assessment (2014) — The ASA cautions that teacher effects typically account for a small fraction of test score variance and that VAM estimates can be unstable and sensitive to model choices. Implication: Basing pay on test-based “merit” risks measurement error and unfairness if used as a high-stakes determinant.
content.source_3: Dee and Wyckoff (2015, Journal of Policy Analysis and Management) on D.C. IMPACT — Evaluation of Washington, DC’s high-powered evaluation system found that strong incentives and dismissal threats improved performance of teachers near rating thresholds and led to the exit of low performers. Implication: Merit-linked pay and consequences can raise effectiveness when embedded in a comprehensive evaluation system.
content.source_4: Springer et al. (2010, Project on Incentives in Teaching, Nashville experiment) — A randomized trial offering sizable individual bonuses to middle school math teachers found no significant gains in student achievement. Implication: Merit pay via bonuses alone, absent broader supports or accountability structures, may not improve outcomes.
content.source_5: Muralidharan and Sundararaman (2011, Journal of Political Economy) — A randomized experiment in India showed that teacher performance pay (both individual and group incentives) produced sustained test score gains, including on non-incentivized subjects. Implication: In some contexts, well-designed merit incentives can boost learning, suggesting design and setting matter.
content.source_6: Economic Policy Institute (2010), “Problems With the Use of Student Test Scores to Evaluate Teachers” (Baker, Barton, Darling-Hammond, Haertel, Ladd, Ravitch, Rothstein, Shavelson, Shepard) — Reviews evidence that test-based evaluations can be biased by student sorting, narrow the curriculum, and disadvantage teachers in high-poverty schools. Implication: Merit pay tied to test scores may create inequities and perverse incentives, undermining broader educational goals.
